This game is truly the epitome of a PERFECT work of art. It was everything I have ever wanted plus many things I never even knew I wanted. It is visually beyond stunning, with characters that you will NEVER forget, and a dynamic story that is mind-blowing to say the least. I personally hold this up as the greatest game I have ever played and probably ever will play. And I have played a large number of hugely critically acclaimed games throughout the years. The core gameplay is a shooter but at no point did it feel redundant. the combat mechanics, and vast amounts of fighting abilities are so well done, that makes each fire of your weapon and vigor great fun and rewarding. The whole series is unique and beautiful but, for me, Infinite takes the cake. I strongly urge anyone to play this game. A 10/10 doesn't even remotely do it justice. I would love to shake the hand of all the creators who made this wonderful, impactful journey possible for me. It truly is everything that could ever be right about a modern video game and then some. So anyway, buy the game, let it envelope you, keep your brain allert and thinking because this game, excuse me, piece of ART, will certaily ''shock'' and amaze you!

This is one of those games I just don't understand the hype for or how it's got so many positive reviews.  The ones saying to buy it and you won't regret it in particular were big fat liars for me.
Hence why Im writing this review even if I normally don't bother with such things. It's probably going to be an unpopular opinion going by the masses of hyperbolic reviews that read more like gushing love letters yet get a ton of upvotes seemingly for just liking the game (tbf that's a problem I see in steam reviews in general) but sod it, I don't care about being downvoted so long as I spare a few people wasting their money like I did.

The gunplay and overall gameplay is mediocre to dull, arguably the most boring set of weapons I've wielded in an fps in a long time  and it was a painful slog playing through with little excitement outside cutscenes where a lot of cool stuff happens but the actual game lacks tension, exarceberated by the games overall easy difficulty, even on hard mode. Apparently there's an old school mode but I'll be damned if I have to replay the game to experience it.

You get an item called a skyhook which you use to grapple onto railings and travel around , but I found whatever thrill is artifically created there as you swoosh around evaporates when you realize even if you were to somehow mess up and fall off the railings to your doom or just stumble of a ledge, you'd get no penalty and just respawn on a ledge with a flash.It's another little thing that helps you feel less like an action star and more like a passenger being taken for the game's boring ride.

It's not like I'm new to this series , I quite enjoyed Bioshock, this just felt like a pale imitation of that game at best only with a lot more bloom.  

As for the story.. Well the fact it couldn't keep my interest going and I ended up not finishing the game and getting buyers remorse should say it all. I ended up watching an LP to see if I missed anything and nope, I even guessed the twist midway through (and I'm no smarty pants). 
 If one finds the twist(s) of this game so amazing then actual twists like that found in games like KOTOR would presumably give these people heart attacks due to being so easily impressed.
The story is functional but hardly some narrative masterpiece.

The setting is probably the best thing about the game (city in the skies and all that) but even then it was hardly enough to motivate me to see it through. One of the draws is meant to be Elizabeth I guess but Booker was a boring protagonist so I didn't feel much in their interaction. And for a "smart" AI partner Elizabeth sure had a bad habit of getting herself noticed by guards whenever I tried being stealthy in an effort to avoid tedious combat and just blitz through. Other then hiding in a corner in combat she throws you items from time to time, but as I was finding the game easy enough already it wasn't something I was particularly grateful for.

An Elizabeth related game mechanic (she's a girl who can travel different parallel universes via portals call "tears") is your ability to access "tears" at certain set pieces of the game to summon things like ammo supplies or turrets or minor structures and platforms from which to navigate whichever section you're in. I didn't feel strongly about this one way or another.

How this game is anyone's idea of a"10/10" leaves me wondering what they have been smoking. Were we even playing the same game?  
Then again I'm a bit old fashioned in that there ain't a lot of games I'd give a 10/10 to and this one barely reaches a 6 in my book, mainly cos its functional and I guess pretty. Don't believe the hype, this game is no perfect gem and even within its own genre there are far better FPS games to play, which reminds me...
I bought Shadow Warrior at a similar time to this game and had a lot more fun with it, I guess in a way contrasting these 2 games helps clarify why I hated Bioshock Infinite so much, SW is more of a classic FPS with a focus on the gameplay, Bioshock Infinite is more of a spectacle FPS where the gameplay is secondary to the story it's trying to tell you aswell as trying to wow you with its setting. If you find the story palpatable you'll enjoy the ride even if the gameplay is mediocre and serves only to connect one cutscene to the next, but if like in my case the story leaves you cold or unimpressed, then there is very little to keep your interest in the game. And Lo Wang from SW plus his demon buddy are a much more likeable pair then Booker and Elizabeth in my book, difference is I guess Elizabeth physically follows you around whereas the demon speaks inside your head.

In conclusion, if you're after an FPS with fun or challenging gameplay, B:I is not that FPS and there are far worthier titles out there.

The FPS mechanics and vigors(special abilities) aren't at all complex or important to use. The combat systems are rather satisfying and offer variance for your personal style and expression. Choosing which gun to upgrade or your favourite vigors is up to you without detracting from effectiveness. Things go flying around and it's a very visceral experience no matter which methods you choose. Some of the deaths actually become quite gruesome.

It's not the combat that's special about this game though. At it's core it's very simplistic and enemies don't offer much of any challenge. The combat is more for a sense of pacing and the feeling urgency or distress you may feel. It was used to great narrative effect in this way. The reason this game gets such high reviews is for the overall cohesive experience the player gets.

They story is played out in the classic Bioshock/System Shock method. It's almost entirely linear with very little back tracking. The atmosphere and tone goes for a 1900-1920's type of optimism and environment. With dialogue and set building that enforces this. The use of lighting and colours is taken into consideration to create proper setting and feel to each area. Or rather, in some instances a stark contrast. One of the tougher enemies, the motorized patriot is a good example of this.

The motorized patriots are robots designed to look like founding fathers that go around trying to kill you with a gatling gun. The design of these enemies is really quite something to behold and in and of itself can serve as a metaphor for the city of Columbia. Dressed in colonial garb, they have 2 flags sticking out of their backs that drape behind them like angelic wings. 

They use the dialogue in this game to great effect. My advice is, when someone starts talking, stop and listen. The line deliveries are very well done and are very short and concise. Metaphors and imagery permeate the dialogues with not a single wasted word.

I feel the way the game tells the story through visuals, sounds, and mechanics is top notch. Insofar as the plot goes, I feel there are some plot holes and some of the character motivation isn't entirely clear even after finishing the game. I suppose that can be argued.

In any event, the game is really good! Get it!

[b]Things I liked:[/b]

[list]
[*] Polished game; few glitches (and no truly significant ones that I encountered)
[*] Good dialogues and voice acting
[*] Lots of small details that makes the game world come alive and about as lifelike as games have come thus far
[*] Good music and sound effects
[*] I like the fact that you have choices here and there, although I haven't tested out yet how much impact they have (presumably not too much?).
[*] I also like that it took quite a while before the combat part of the game actually started, and that there also later were parts completely without it (i.e. no passive combat (where you can only sit back and watch), either)
[*] Looks pretty and runs smoothly
[/list]

[b]Things I didn't like:[/b]

[list]
[*] Ghost(s). Please no more ghosts!
[*] Maybe there's a good reason for it, but not being able to save the game yourself is a bit frustrating when you feel you've played enough for now, and is not interested in having the game running on the PC.
[*] A [i]very[/i] important plot feature does not really appear to be supported by its own premises. If there's an infinite number of you-know-what, then that which they did would not have the effect it is insinuated as having. There would be endless examples of you-know-what where they did not do it or failed to do it and where bad things would happen anyway. Infinity is infinity.
[*] The game is long, but could probably have been somewhat longer (but any additions should of course advance the plot and/or expand on it rather act as pure fillers; something BioShock 1 had (like the dying vegetation, *yawn*))
[/list]

All in all, it's a decent and solid game, for the most part. But that plot...

Pros: The game has a fantastic and engaging ambiance, and it's very pretty too. I dig the setting.

Cons: I couldn't put my distaste for the cadence of this game into words until my friend said it; this is a railshooter disguised as an FPS/RPG. I could forgive the mechanics putting me to sleep, but I also felt like the characters were unbelievable. The protagonist tries too hard to be dark and brooding. He's constantly bringing up things he doesn't want to talk about, like a Vaguebook drama queen, thereby immediately careening any potential vehicle of intrigue into a brick wall of irritation. The female lead has a capricious and flaky personality that makes her impossible to follow. I tried to hang on but it lost me. I would still give Bioshock another shot in the future if they tried again. I like their world setting and it's evident they have a team of talented people; I think this game mostly suffered from poor execution.

Com uma história boa, graficos lindos e uma otima jogabilidade, BioShock Infinite concerteza é o game certo pra quem curte games de tiro em primeira pessoa (fps).
   A historia do game se passa antes dos dois primeiros games da série BioShock, mais especificamente no ano de 1912 na cidade de Columbia, apesar de a trama parecer simples no começo do game, com o passar do tempo ela se torna bem mais complexa, chegando até mesmo a se tornar confusa e de difícil compreensão numa certa parte, mas que se resolve no final e deixa tudo bem esclarecido. Os personagen são bem convincentes, principalmente Elizabeth, que é muito carismática e de total importançia na trama do jogo, Booker DeWitt é o personagem princpal do game (apesar de Elizabeth se destacar), ele é enviado a Columbia para resgatar Elizabeth das mãos de Zachary Hale Comstock, vilão do game e tambem connhecido como "o Profeta", lider religioso da cidade, que alias, tem um senso de justiça e ética bem deturpado.
  O grafico é lindo e meio cartunisado, a ciade voadora de Columbia é linda (isso mesmo uma cidade que vôa), a ambientação dos anos 10 é ótima e bem detalhada, e conta com o figurino e arquitetura das construções da época. Os efeitos de iluminção e sombra do game também mereçem destaque.
  A mecanica do game é praticamente a mesma dos games anteriores, mas temos algumas coisas a mais, como a adição dos aérotrilhos que deixou a jogabilidade bem mais frenética e alguns "poderes" diferentes. A quantidade de armas é bem grande, sendo que, temos modelos do exercito de Comstock e Vox Populi .Os modelos da Vox tem algumas  modificações que deixam as coisas mais explosivas.
   Bem essas são minhas opiniôes sobre o game por isso espero que a respeitem, obrigado desde já, HerculesLF.

(No Story Spoilers) This game is a few years old. I think I got it last year 2013 Black Friday sale and it sat on my hard drive for a year. I was pretty bored by Bioshock 2, but I really liked Infinite. After playing The Last of Us on the PS3, and experiencing that amazing story, I was worried I wouldn't be satisfied by anything else. And even though Infinite came out a couple years before The Last of Us, this was still a very solid story. Like TLoU this story has 2 characters that I really cared about and wanted to see what would happen. The level design is really great overall and the weapons are varied and imaginative. The new "Vigor" (still called plasmids) in the menu's and dialog text is also well done. I tend not to bother too much wiyth magic powers if I have guns in a video game but in this case it's almost required. Bucking Bronco was the one I used the most. I also loved the Carbine rifle, single shot simi-auto and hits hard, espececially for head shots and after a few upgrades. And who doesn't love a good ricket launcher? That was always my favorite secondary weapon. It hits REALLY hard, especially after a few upgrades. Speaking of upgrades, the weapons have an upgrade system. At first it seems outragiously expensive, but slowly money becomes easier and easier to find. One thing about the Carbine that was a little annoying was that it was very hard to find ammo for large parts of the game, I would often have to stock up at a "Dollar Bill" when ever I saw one and top off my ammo. Controls where also very good, I am an old school keyboard and mouse player, but I can manage with a game pad. I didn't try a gamepad with this game, but I can say the mouse & keyboard was tight yet a bit weighty, I like that. Load times on my 2 year old upper mid tier gameing PC was also very good. 

Some niggling complaints about the game. The graphics are very good so when I see the things that I'm about to talk about it kind of pulls me out of the realism of the game a bit. When you walk up to some birds outdoors they fly away if you get too close. If you do that indoors, they fly up into the ceiling through the wall. The characher you protect and you follow around or she followsd you, casts a shadowm but you don't. Sort of understandable since you don't have a body, look down, nothing. But that's common. The pother NPC's with very minor roles, just seem like stiff mannequins. 

Again nothing major, just there. The world is linear but BIG, I can't expect full realism even with such a hiugh quality game. Oh also the sound was INCREDIBLE! Amazing music, dialoge, and other ways to immerse you. 

Other than that, the game never crashed on me once, and I never saw a single graphic glitch.

So yeah, great sotry, great game, great graphics. If you like a great story driven FPS with very mild RPG elements, this is one you should play.

Bioshock Infinite: The review

Bioshock infinite starts off at a lighthouse. It then proceeds up in the skies, where you get greeted by amazing scenery up in the sky. 
You will encounter: Hummingbirds, a shinign sun,  rose bushes and people who seems to be happy. 
 You approach a society where racism is more strong than today, it is noticable in the beginning by several posters hanging on the walls, but other than that, everything seems so perfect. The racism part becomes more clear further into the game. 

It goes from this Idyllic phase into a dark and more deeper phase. I love the originality of all the enemies and characters, I love the envoirments, I love all the extra-things you can find. Instead of just following a straight line in the game, (from the beginning to the end) you get to find power ups and other secrets. 
It is  a nice change from being under water to be able to travel around in the sky. 

I love how well polished Elizabeth was, it all felt so real somehow. 
If you love FPS with fun fighting scenes, great story and plot twists, this game is for you!

This is a worthy successor of the previous games in the series. The action is just as fun and interesting as before, with some new powers through Vigors and cool combinations you can set up with them. Half of the game is an escort mission, but unlike in other games, the person you're escorting actually helps you, stays out of the way and takes care of herself during fights, which is a very refreshing change of pace. Fighting in the streets and skies of Columbia is an incredibly fun experience, knocking people off the edge of the city, jumping around on cargo hooks before landing on an enemy and crushing their skull, facing overwhelming odds until you have Elizabeth call in an auto-turret to shoot and distract your enemies.

And then there's the story. You probably already know that this was one of the most talked-about stories of 2013, and it definitely deserved to be. You've got everything from time travel to alternate realities to a twist worthy of the original Bioshock, and it's a great ride the entire time. One caveat I would mention, though, is that if you are a fan of the full series of Bioshock, you should get the Burial at Sea DLC and play through that as well once you finish with Infinite. Infinite's story can stand on its own, but the DLC connects the entire series together in a way that was both very satisfying and very surprising. I'm normally fairly "meh" about DLC, but the ones for this game really added something, I felt.

So really, there's not much point in me writing this review: you probably already know if you want this game or not. If you've played other Bioshock games, if you like FPSes, if you enjoy a great story in your games with plenty of twists and turns, then just buy this game. If it looks like anything you might like, I can almost guarantee that you will. So just buy it already.
